because it actually checks what I want - whether the model is installed, not whether the name of the applications is in a list of installed applications

ok
class based views are heavenly!
please don't do the getattr on the module level, ever!
._meta.installed will only be true if it's used in that project, not when if it's just present
@JoshMock no! You would just use that if you actualy wanted to change ALL the TextFieldsa to use TinyMCE for example
thread safety, overridability of settings in runtime, etc
Is this trying to sell me Java portlets?
please don't test for values in 'INSTALLED_APPS', just try import the model and check model._meta.installed
why do you prefer that?
seems like they should be functionally equivalent
_meta is not a guaranteed api
it's just a matter of personal taste
but strings are how you install apps in Django...
explicitness
yes, try: except ImportError:, that's not a lot of extra typing
Really shouldn't be touching _meta outside of core django imo
@HonzaKral it also tells you how django's going to interact with it (if it's not in INSTALLED_APPS syncdb won't create tables for it, templatetags won't be loaded, &c.)
but I agree with the point that you probably don't want to rely on _meta
so you'd have to set a custom type for your fields to use that?
@justquick that was just to import it, you then have to check the _meta.installed for the useful part, I explicitely stated that
@HonzaKral but whether or not it's in INSTALLED_APPS tells you more than whether or not it's installed
fair enough :)
you can usually just use formfield_overrides on ModelAdmin, which is already a dictionaty that you can use, the downside is that it uses the db_field's type to do the matching, not it's name
though I feel like the inherent readability of using strings makes it a desirable way to go. 'app_name' in INSTALLED_APPS is so much more readily understandable than app_name._meta.installed is True
but I agree that it's purely personal taste
@joshourisman which I hope will change eventually :)
gotcha. I was gonna say...
yeah, if you want to change them ALL, then formfield_overrides is totally the way to go
yeah, name is much better, in my opinion; it's not at all uncommon that I have different requirements for different TextFields on the same model
just wanted to be clear
@HonzaKral just because you can import a module doesnt mean that you have/want it installed in your project
try: except ImportError  bit
